utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, guys, guys, some of the other waitresses wanted me to ask you something.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, it’s called trestling.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It combines the physical strength of arm wrestling with the mental agility of tetris into the ultimate sport.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s terrific, but what they wanted me to ask you was to cut it the hell out. Right come on guys, come on. Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We might as well stop, it’s a stalemate. You’re beating me in tetris, but you’ve got the upper body strength of a Keebler Elf.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Keebler Elf? I’ve got your Keebler Elf right here. Okay, it’s a stalemate.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So Leonard, will we be seeing you on Saturday for your free birthday cheesecake?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: He can’t eat cheesecake, he’s lactose intolerant.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, he can have carrot cake.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What about the cream cheese frosting.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: he can scrape it off.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Forget about the cake, how did you know that my birthday is Saturday?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I did your horoscope, remember, I was going to do everybody’s until Sheldon went on one of his typical psychotic rants.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: For the record, that psychotic rant was a concise summation of the research of Bertram Forer, who in 1948 proved conclusively through meticulously designed experiments, that astrology is nothing but pseudo scientific hokum.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Blah blah blah, a typical Taurus. So, seriously, are we going to see you Saturday?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, I don’t think so.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t celebrate my birthday.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Shuddup, yeah you do.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, it’s no big deal, it’s just the way I was raised. My parents focussed on celebrating achievements, and being expelled from a birth canal was not considered one of them.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, that’s so silly.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s actually based on very sound theories, his mother published a paper on it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What was it called, “I hate my son and that’s why he can’t have cake?”

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It was obviously effective, Leonard grew up to be an experimental physicist. Perhaps if she’d also denied him Christmas he’d be a little better at it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well I love birthdays, waking up to Mom’s special French Toast breakfast, wearing the birthday king crown, playing laser tag with all my friends.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, see, that’s what kids should have.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Actually that was last year.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So you’ve really never had a birthday party?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No. But it was okay. I mean, when I was little I’d think maybe my parents would change their mind, and surprise me with a party, like this one birthday I came home from my Cello lesson, and I saw a lot of strange cars parked out front, and when I got to the door I could hear people whispering, and I could smell German chocolate cake, which is my favourite.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, it turns out my grandfather had died.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh my God, that’s terrible.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, it was kind of like a birthday party. I got to see all my cousins and there was cake, so…7

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That’s the saddest thing I’ve ever heard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You think? Go ahead, tell her about your senior prom.

utterance.speaker: Howard (voice from inside)
utterance.content: Make sure they remember no peanuts.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Howard, every Thai restaurant in town knows you can’t eat peanuts. They see me coming they go “ah, no peanut boy!”

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (answering)
utterance.content: Hello Penny. Leonard just left.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I know. I want to talk to you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What would we talk about? We’ve no overlapping areas of interest I’m aware of, and you know I don’t care for chit-chat.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, can you just let me in.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well alright, but I don’t see this as a promising endeavour.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, here’s the deal, we are going to throw Leonard a kick-ass surprise party for his birthday on Saturday.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I hardly think so, Leonard made it very clear he doesn’t want a party.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Did someone say party?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: He just doesn’t know he wants one because he’s never had one.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I suppose that’s possible, but for the record, I’ve never had a threesome and yet I still know I want one.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Howard, here’s the difference. The possibility exists that Leonard could have a birthday party before hell freezes over.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Fine. If I do have a threesome, you can’t be part of it. I’m just kidding, yes you can. Can you bring a friend?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I think a birthday party is a terrible idea. I envy Leonard for growing up without that anguish.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Anguish?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Year after year, I had to endure wearing conical hats while being forced into the crowded sweaty hell of bouncy castles, not to mention being blindfolded and spun towards a grotesque tailless donkey as the other children mocked my disorientation.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, sweetie, I understand you have scars that no non-professional can heal, but nevertheless we are going to throw Leonard a birthday party.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Have I pointed out that I am extremely uncomfortable with dancing, loud music and most other forms of alcohol induced frivolity.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Nevertheless we are….

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In addition I really don’t think that Leonard wants a…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, here’s the deal, you either help me throw Leonard a birthday party or, so help me God, I will go into your bedroom and I will unbag all of your most valuable mint condition comic books. And on one of them, you won’t know which, I’ll draw a tiny happy face in ink.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You can’t do that, if you make a mark on a mint comic book it’s no longer mint.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, do you understand the concept of blackmail?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well of course I… oh! Yeah, I have an idea, let’s throw Leonard a kick ass birthday party.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s not the secret knock. This is the secret knock.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What difference does it make?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The whole point of a secret knock is to establish a non-verbal signal to verify the identity of one’s co-conspirators.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Is that Raj and Howard?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Possibly, but unverified.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Can you just let us in.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Luckily for you this is not a nuclear reactor.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, what did you get the birthday boy?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, Raj got him an awesome limited edition Dark Knight sculpture based on Alex Ross’s definitive Batman, and I got him this amazing autographed copy of the Feynman lectures on physics.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Nice. I got him a sweater.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, well, he might like that, I’ve seen him… chilly.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, Sheldon, I didn’t see your present.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s because I didn’t bring one.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well why not?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t ask.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The entire institution of gift giving makes no sense.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Too late.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Let’s say that I go out and I spend fifty dollars on you, it’s a laborious activity, because I have to imagine what you need, whereas you know what you need. Now I can simplify things, just give you the fifty dollars directly and, you could give me fifty dollars on my birthday, and so on until one of us dies leaving the other one old and fifty dollars richer. And I ask you, is it worth it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Told you not to ask.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, Sheldon, you’re his friend. Friends give each other presents.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I accept your premise, I reject your conclusion.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Try telling him it’s a non-optional social convention.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Just do it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s a non-optional social convention.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh. Fair enough.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: He came with a manual.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Question, how am I going to get Leonard a present before the party? I don’t drive, and the only things available within walking distance are a Thai restaurant and a gas station. I suppose I could wrap up an order of mee krob and a couple of lottery scratchers.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, let’s do this, um, I will drive Sheldon to get a present, and Howard, you need to get rid of Leonard for about two hours.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No problem.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: And then Raj, you bring the stuff across the hall and start setting up.

utterance.speaker: Howard (after Raj whispers in his ear)
utterance.content: What if guests show up?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Entertain them.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What if they’re women?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Stare at them and make them feel uncomfortable.

utterance.speaker: Howard (entering)
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: How’s it going?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, listen, the New Art is showing the revised definitive cut of Blade Runner.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Seen it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, you’ve seen the 25th anniversary final cut. This one has eight seconds of previously unseen footage. They say it completely changes the tone of the film.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. Pass.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Come on, afterwards there’s a Q _ A with Harrison Ford’s body double.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, I am in the Halo battle of my life here, there’s this kid in Copenhagen, he has no immune system so all he does is sit in his bubble and play Halo 24/7.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Can’t you play him some other time?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Not if you believe his doctors.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh my God, do you smell gas.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, no.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Alright, you know they have DVDs over there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, but they have DVD burners over here. Leonard needs a DVD burner.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, a gift shouldn’t be something someone needs, it should be something fun, you know, something they wouldn’t buy for themselves.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You mean, like a sweater?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, it’s a fun sweater, it’s got a bold geometric print.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is it the geometry that makes it fun.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, the point is, one of the ways we show we care about people is by putting thought and imagination into the gifts we give them.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, I see, so not a DVD burner.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Exactly.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Something he wouldn’t buy for himself. Something fun. Something like… oh, an 802.11n wireless router.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Here you go, Copenhagen boy, how about a taste of Hans Christian Hand Grenade. Come on, come on, oh you clever little…. Come on, come on, take that!

utterance.speaker: Howard (picks up a granola bar from the table, breaks off half and puts it in his back pocket.)
utterance.content: Oh-oh. Oh-oh!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s the matter?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: This granola bar, there’s peanuts in it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh my God, why did you eat it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know, it was just there.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well if I had a gun there, would you have shot yourself?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t yell at me, I’ve got to go to the emergency room.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Now?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, after my tongue has swollen to the size of a brisket.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Alright, um, just, uh, let me get my keys.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh God, oh God, oh God, oh…. The laundry is out of the hamper. Okay Sheldon, what was it supposed to be? Fine, it’s out of the washer. I’ll call you when it’s in the dryer.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (running in)
utterance.content: Alright, let’s go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What do you think.

utterance.speaker: Penny (pointing randomly)
utterance.content: Um, that one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Because of the two additional Ethernet ports.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: He doesn’t need them, he’s already got a 640 connect switch

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, okay then this one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know, the man on the box looks so happy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny! If I’m going to buy Leonard a gift, I’m going to do it right. I refuse to let him experience the same childhood trauma I did.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, I know I’m going to regret this but, what trauma?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: On my twelfth birthday I really wanted a titanium centrifuge, so, you know, I could separate radioactive isotopes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Instead of a titanium centrifuge, my parents bought me… wow, this is hard. They got me… a motorised dirt bike.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What twelve year old boy wants a motorised dirt bike?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All of them.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Huh?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, so we’re getting this one?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, I suppose.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, let’s go.

utterance.speaker: Random woman
utterance.content: Excuse me, do you know anything about this stuff?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know everything about this stuff.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: Okay, I have my own wholesale flower business, and I want to hook up my computer in the front entrance with the one in my refrigerated warehouse.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Here, buy this one. Look, it’s the one we’re getting, see, happy guy available.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, no, no, she doesn’t want that, she needs a point to point peer network with a range extender.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Random guy
utterance.content: Which hard drive do I want, firewire or USB?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It depends on what Bus you have.

utterance.speaker: Guy
utterance.content: I drive a Chevy Cavalier.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, dear lord.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, we have to go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not now, Penny, this poor man needs me. You hold on, I’ll be right with you. What computer do you have, and please don’t say a white one?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Fill this out, have a seat.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, listen, see we’re throwing my friend a surprise party and I’m supposed to keep him out of his apartment for two hours.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Uh-huh, fill this out and have a seat.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, see, the only way I could get him to leave is to tell him I ate a peanut. Because I’m allergic to peanuts.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Oh, well in that case fill this out and have a seat.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Look, all I need from you is to take me in the back and give me a band-aid so I can pretend I had a shot of epinephrine and they you tell my friend you need to keep me under observation for about an hour, hour and a half.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Is that all you need?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Get out of my ER.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, you don’t understand.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Oh, I understand, but unfortunately this hospital is not equipped to treat stupid.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, I get it, I know how the world works, how about if I were to introduce you to the man who freed your people.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (running in)
utterance.content: Hey, sorry I couldn’t find a parking spot, how are you doing.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Bad, very bad.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really, ‘cos you don’t look like you’re swelling up at all, maybe we should just pick up some benedryl at the drug store and go home.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We can’t go home.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Becauth Becauth-th-th. Brissket, Brissket! Water, need water.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Alright, I’ll be right back.

utterance.speaker: Howard (into phone)
utterance.content: Penny, look, I’ve got a problem.

utterance.speaker: Penny (with Sheldon in background at the head of a large queue of customers)
utterance.content: Yeah, well so do I, look you’ve got to stall Leonard a little longer.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t think I can.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You have to, we all have to be there at the same time to yell “surprise!”

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, you have to understand something, we’re in a hospital right now.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Why, is Leonard okay.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Leonard’s fine. I’m fine, thanks for asking, by the way.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I don’t need your attitude, just hold him there a little longer.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Look, I’ve done my best but he wants to go home and I don’t know how to stop him.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, how about this. You keep him there a little longer and when you get to the party I’ll point out which of my friends are easy.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t toy with me, woman.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’ve got a hot former fat girl with no self-esteem, I’ve got a girl who punishes her father by sleeping around and an alcoholic who’s two tequila shots away from letting you wear her like a hat.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thy will be done. I’m doing this for you, little buddy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, we don’t have that in stock, but I can special order it for you.

utterance.speaker: Penny (with shop assistant, points at Sheldon)
utterance.content: Him.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Excuse me, sir, you don’t work here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, well, apparently neither does anyone else.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, we have to go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, for one thing, we’re late for Leonard’s birthday party. And for another, I told him to call security.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (to customer)
utterance.content: Good luck. By the way, a six year-old could hack your computer system.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Keep walking.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, 1-2-3-4 is not a secure password.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Excuse me, my friend is having an allergic reaction to peanuts.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: No he’s not.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes he is.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Look, sir we are very busy here and I just don’t… holy crap!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Pees hep me!

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Code 4, I need a gurney, right away, right away.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Fank-u.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Say what you will about the healthcare system in this country, but when they’re afraid of lawsuits they sure test everything.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I really don’t think the colonoscopy was necessary.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, before you got all swollen up, I actually thought you were trying to keep me out of the apartment so you could throw me a surprise party.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, right, it’s your birthday, I had no idea it was your birthday, I completely forgot, wow, what a lousy way to spend a birthday, well it’s all over now.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There is a party, isn’t there.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Maybe.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Howard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Are you mad?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: how could I be mad? You actually risked your life because you cared about me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s why I did it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Alright. Here we go. My first birthday party.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Dude! Everybody left an hour ago! Surprise!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay Leonard, here I am at your birthday party, I don’t know where you are dude, but it’s really kick-ass. Everyone is very very drunk, and uh… Oh look, there’s a girl taking her shirt off.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That’s my friend Carol. Remind me, I’ve got to introduce her to Howard.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh sweet Krishna, shake it, that-a rupee maker.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m so sorry you didn’t get your party.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, it’s okay.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Happy birthday anyways.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey Penny, when, uh, when’s your birthday?
